metadata.description: Comprehensive Bash and Unix command reference with examples, covering 80+ commands and bash constructs with detailed arguments, examples, and use cases. Includes 500+ practical examples across networking, system administration, file management, process control, package management, user management, and more.

commands.short_desc: Transfer data from or to a server using various protocols
commands.description: curl is a command-line tool for transferring data using various network protocols. It supports HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, FTPS, and many others. Commonly used for API testing, file downloads, and web scraping.

arguments.-X, --request: Specifies the HTTP method (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH, etc.)
arguments.-H, --header: Adds a custom HTTP header to the request (can be used multiple times)
arguments.-d, --data: Sends data in the body of a POST request (implies POST method)
arguments.-o, --output: Writes output to a file instead of stdout
arguments.-O, --remote-name: Saves file with the same name as the remote file
arguments.-s, --silent: Silences curl's progress meter and error messages
arguments.-S, --show-error: Shows errors even when -s is used
arguments.-v, --verbose: Enables verbose output showing request/response headers and SSL info
arguments.-i, --include: Includes HTTP response headers in the output
arguments.-u, --user: Specifies username and password for server authentication (user:password)
arguments.-b, --cookie: Sends cookies from a file or string
arguments.-c, --cookie-jar: Saves cookies to a file after the request
arguments.-k, --insecure: Allows insecure SSL connections (skips certificate verification)
arguments.-F, --form: Sends data as multipart/form-data (for file uploads)
arguments.-T, --upload-file: Uploads a file to the server
arguments.--compressed: Requests compressed response and automatically decompresses
arguments.--max-time: Sets maximum time allowed for the transfer (in seconds)
arguments.-w, --write-out: Formats output with variables (e.g., http_code, time_total)
arguments.--retry: Retries the request on transient errors
arguments.-C, --continue-at: Continues a partial download from the specified offset
arguments.-J, --remote-header-name: Uses the header-provided filename when saving
arguments.--data-binary: Posts data exactly as specified with no processing
arguments.--cert: Uses the specified client certificate file
arguments.--key: Uses the specified private key file
arguments.--cacert: Uses the specified CA certificate for verification

commands.short_desc: Bash conditional statements and test operators
commands.description: Conditional statements allow scripts to make decisions and execute different code paths based on conditions.

if_statement.syntax:
if [ condition ]; then
  commands
elif [ condition ]; then
  commands
else
  commands
fi

examples.explanation: Check if file exists

  echo "Running as root"
else
  echo "Not root"
fi

  echo "Count is greater than 10"

file_tests.-f file: True if file exists and is a regular file
file_tests.-d file: True if file exists and is a directory
file_tests.-L file: True if file exists and is a symbolic link
file_tests.-r file: True if file exists and is readable
file_tests.-w file: True if file exists and is writable
file_tests.-x file: True if file exists and is executable
file_tests.-s file: True if file exists and has size > 0
file_tests.file1 -nt file2: True if file1 is newer than file2
file_tests.file1 -ot file2: True if file1 is older than file2

string_tests.-z string: True if string length is zero

string_tests.str1 < str2: True if str1 sorts before str2
string_tests.str1 > str2: True if str1 sorts after str2

case_statement.syntax:
case $variable in
  pattern1)
    commands
    ;;
  pattern2|pattern3)
    commands
    ;;
  *)
    default commands
    ;;
esac

examples.code:

    ;;
  stop)

    ;;
  *)

esac

commands.description: blkid is used to display information about available block devices. It can determine the type of content (e.g. filesystem or swap) that a block device holds, and attributes (tokens, NAME=value pairs) from the content metadata (e.g. UUID or LABEL).

arguments.-c file: Use specified cache file instead of default
arguments.-i: Show I/O limits (alignment, minimum I/O size, etc.)
arguments.-l: Look up one device matching search parameter
arguments.-L label: Look up device with specified label
arguments.-o format: Output format (value, device, list, full, export, udev)
arguments.-t name: Search for devices with specified token
arguments.-U uuid: Look up device with specified UUID

examples.explanation: List all block devices with their UUIDs, labels, and filesystem types

Find device by UUID
Find device by filesystem label

Get only the UUID value for a device (useful in scripts)

common_combinations: blkid | grep ext4 - Find all ext4 partitions
UUID=$(blkid -s UUID -o value /dev/sda1) - Get UUID in variable
blkid -o list | column -t - Formatted list view

commands.short_desc: Convert and copy a file with low-level byte-by-byte operations
commands.description: dd is a utility for low-level copying and conversion of raw data. It can copy data from one file/device to another, perform byte-level operations, create disk images, write ISOs to USB drives, and more. CAUTION: dd is powerful and dangerous - incorrect usage can destroy data!

arguments.if=FILE: Read from FILE instead of stdin (input file)
arguments.of=FILE: Write to FILE instead of stdout (output file)
arguments.bs=BYTES: Read and write BYTES bytes at a time (block size)
arguments.ibs=BYTES: Read BYTES bytes at a time (input block size)
arguments.obs=BYTES: Write BYTES bytes at a time (output block size)
arguments.skip=N: Skip N input blocks at start
arguments.seek=N: Skip N output blocks at start
arguments.conv=CONVS: Convert file as per comma separated symbol list
arguments.iflag=FLAGS: Read as per comma separated symbol list
arguments.oflag=FLAGS: Write as per comma separated symbol list

examples.explanation: Clone entire disk /dev/sda to /dev/sdb with progress indicator (DANGEROUS! Double-check device names!)

examples.code: dd if=ubuntu.iso of=/dev/sdb bs=4M status=progress && sync

dd if=file.iso | pv | dd of=/dev/sdb - Use pv for progress bar

commands.short_desc: High-level package management command-line interface for Debian/Ubuntu
commands.description: apt is the modern command-line interface for the Debian package management system. It provides a user-friendly interface to the most commonly used features from apt-get and apt-cache. Designed for interactive use.

arguments.full-upgrade: Upgrade with package additions/removals if needed
arguments.autoremove: Remove automatically installed dependencies no longer needed
arguments.edit-sources: Edit sources list in default editor
arguments.-s, --simulate: Simulate actions without actually performing them

commands.short_desc: Execute a command as another user (typically root)
commands.description: sudo allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser (root) or another user, as specified by the security policy configured in /etc/sudoers. It logs all commands and arguments.

arguments.-u user: Run command as specified user (default is root)
arguments.-s: Run shell specified by SHELL environment variable
arguments.-H: Set HOME to target user's home directory
arguments.-k: Invalidate cached credentials (force password prompt next time)
arguments.-l: List allowed commands for current user
arguments.-S: Read password from stdin instead of terminal

commands.short_desc: Create a new user or update default new user information
commands.description: useradd creates a new user account using the values specified on the command line plus default values from the system. It's a low-level utility; some distributions prefer 'adduser' which is more interactive.

arguments.-m, --create-home: Create home directory if it doesn't exist
arguments.-g, --gid: Set primary group (by name or GID)
arguments.-r, --system: Create system account (no home dir, non-expiring)
arguments.-p, --password: Set encrypted password (use passwd instead for security)
arguments.-N, --no-user-group: Don't create a group with same name as user
arguments.-U, --user-group: Create group with same name as user (default)

commands.short_desc: Change user password
commands.description: passwd changes passwords for user accounts. A normal user may only change the password for their own account, while the superuser may change the password for any account. passwd also changes account password expiry information.

arguments.-e, --expire: Expire password immediately (force change on next login)
arguments.-n, --minimum: Set minimum days before password can be changed
arguments.-x, --maximum: Set maximum days before password must be changed
arguments.-w, --warning: Set warning days before password expires
arguments.-i, --inactive: Set days after expiry before account becomes inactive
arguments.--stdin: Read password from stdin (useful in scripts)

examples.explanation: Change your own password (prompts for current and new password)

common_combinations: passwd -l user && passwd -e user - Lock and expire password
passwd -S user - Check password status
chage -l user - View full password aging info

commands.short_desc: Print user and group information for specified user
commands.description: id displays user identity information including user ID (UID), group ID (GID), and groups the user belongs to. Without any username, it shows information for the current user.

commands.short_desc: Show who is logged on
commands.description: who shows information about users who are currently logged in. It reads from /var/run/utmp by default and can display login time, terminal, and remote host.

commands.short_desc: Compress or decompress files using gzip compression
commands.description: gzip reduces file size using Lempel-Ziv coding (LZ77). Each file is replaced by a compressed version with .gz extension. Compressed files can be restored to original form using gzip -d or gunzip.

arguments.-c, --stdout: Write to standard output, keep original files
arguments.-f, --force: Force compression/decompression even if file has links
